vectorData.altText: That's right!  Spermatogonia occupy the basal compartment of the seminiferous tubules.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

The stratified germinal epithelium contains spermatogonia (SG) and Sertoli cells (SC). SG are always in contact with the BL. There are two types of SG, Type A and Type B    . Type A SG are stem cells and undergo mitotic division to give rise to Type A and Type B SG. Type B SG undergo mitotic division to form 1° spermatocytes (PS). PS are found in layers luminal to the SG. PS undergo the first round of meiosis to form 2° spermatocytes which rapidly complete the second meiotic division to form spermatids (LS). This explains why 2° spermatocytes are seldom seen on histological sections.  Sertoli cells (SC) are dispersed between the spermatogenic cells and appear as irregularly shaped columnar cells that extend from the BL to the lumen of the ST. They nourish the developing spermatogenic cells and form the blood-testis-barrier.
This histological image shows a seminiferous tubule. The stratified germinal epithelium (also referred to as seminiferous epithelium) rests on a basal lamina (BL).
H&E staining does not allow one to identify the difference between these two cells.
Type A and Type B SG
